Comment: 1.d4 is my standard opening move with white, so my repertoire mostly contains openings like Queens Gambit, Slav or semi-slav, King's-Queens or Nimzo Indian, Grunfeld, Benko Gambit and Modern Defence systems. With black I only play the Sicilian (Najdorf) against 1.e4.
D06: Queens Gambit. Of course black can play 2...c6, entering the Slav defence.
D06: Queens Gambit. Of course black can play 2...c6, entering the Slav defence.
? But this is not the strongest continuation. Of course its playable, but white usually gets a good position.
The best move of course. Black can't avoid losing a tempo.
If 3...Qxd5? then ofcourse 4.Nc3.
But now white can play e4 straightaway, which is often the goal in these kind of positions.
last bookmove.
?! I decided to set up a cheap trick, but at the same time develop my bishop.
Of course the d4 is poisoned, due to Bb5+, but here black missed a chance to equalise with 5... e5! followed by something like 6. dxe5 Nc6.
Black is somewhat behind in development.
I think 6... Be7 is slightly better.
? Black is already behind in development, so 7... Nc6 was the most logical continuation.
? Black is already behind in development, so 7... Nc6 was the most logical continuation.
White is already 'winning' here. Control of the centre, lead in development, space on the king side and let's not forget the Bishop pair.
Finally the knight comes into play.
? I don't like this move. He should have played 9... O-O while he still had the chance.
? I don't like this move. He should have played 9... O-O while he still had the chance.
But now dark clouds are gathering in the sky. From this square the bishop prevents black from castling.
?? Best was 10... Qf6 and then castling queen side, but this move allows white to come up with a nice tactical blow, so try to find the best move for white now.
